support_summary: ATXN3 directly interacts with tubulin (TUBB), a cytoskeletal protein involved in microtubule-dependent transport and aggresome formation.

functions.cellular_process: ATXN3 directly interacts with α- and β-tubulin, the primary components of microtubules. This interaction is fundamental for the process of sequestering misfolded protein aggregates into a perinuclear inclusion body known as the aggresome, which relies on intact microtubule-based transport.
functions.effect_description: By binding to tubulin, ATXN3 colocalizes with the microtubule network, positioning it to participate in the transport of ubiquitinated, misfolded proteins. This facilitates the movement of these toxic aggregates along microtubule tracks towards the microtubule-organizing center (MTOC), where the aggresome is formed.
biological_consequence: ATXN3 binds directly to tubulin dimers -> ATXN3 colocalizes with the microtubule cytoskeleton -> Misfolded protein aggregates are linked to the microtubule network via ATXN3 and other factors -> Aggregates undergo retrograde transport toward the MTOC -> Aggregates are sequestered into the aggresome.
specific_effects: The direct interaction between ATXN3 and tubulin dimer has a dissociation constant (Kd) of 50-70 nM, indicating a high-affinity binding.
Normal ATXN3 colocalizes with microtubules, whereas the expanded, aggregation-prone form of ATXN3 shows reduced colocalization.

evidence.paper_title: Proteomic and biochemical analyses unveil tight interaction of ataxin-3 with tubulin
evidence.journal: The International Journal of Biochemistry & Cell Biology
evidence.relevant_quote: Furthermore, by surface plasmon resonance we determined a dissociation constant of 50-70nM between ataxin-3 and tubulin dimer, which strongly supports the hypothesis of a direct interaction of this protein with microtubules in vivo. These findings suggest an involvement of ataxin-3 in directing aggregated protein to aggresomes...

evidence.paper_title: Interactions of ataxin-3 with its molecular partners in the protein machinery that sorts protein aggregates to the aggresome
evidence.relevant_quote: AT3 has been implicated in the pathway that sorts aggregated protein to aggresomes via microtubules, in which dynein and histone deacetylase 6 (HDAC6) also seem to be involved. By taking advantage of small angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) and surface plasmon resonance (SPR), we have investigated the interaction of AT3 with tubulin and HDAC6.
